screen_desc: The screenshot shows the search results page on Booking.com's mobile website. The user appears to be searching for accommodations in Buenos Aires from October 11th to October 12th for 2 adults. There are options to sort, filter, and view the search results on a map at the top of the page. A welcome message is also displayed, congratulating the user, Brennan, on receiving Genius Level 1 discounts. There is a prominent "Start searching" button at the bottom, likely aimed at engaging the user to proceed with their search.
action_think: The user requested to open a new Chrome private tab, but the current screen is on Booking.com in the Chrome browser. Since the user has already opened Chrome, the next action should be to access the browser's menu to open a new private tab.
action_plan: Tap the three-dot menu icon in the top-right corner of the screen.
Select 'New incognito tab' from the options.
action_desc: Tap the three-dot menu icon in the top-right corner of the screen.
action_result:
By clicking on the tab switcher icon located at the top right of the screen, the browser interface has opened a menu showing various options such as opening a new tab, accessing bookmarks, and more. This action itself does not directly fulfill the user request, as the menu displayed does not immediately open a new incognito (private) tab.

To complete the user request of opening a new Chrome private tab, the next step would be to select the "New incognito tab" option from the menu. This will create a private browsing session, as required.
